entry.title: Re: Issues with Data Monitor Logs and Manual Posting in G...
entry.content:
Appologies for the late response, you may have sorted out the issue
This is standard behavior in both S/4HANA On‑Premise and S/4HANA Cloud. - Manual posting / 1095 - this task never redirects to the posting screen, since its not a tracking task and not an execution task
If you on S/4 HANA On-Premise you can check the option of enhancing the task type to include navigation (not easy as said!) this would require:
BAdI implementation, Custom task type, Custom UI action
if this is an end user requirement, Train the users on SAP standard behavior

entry.title: Small program to test the SCSM_NW_WORKLOAD interface for reading ABAP statistics data
entry.content:
The "SCSM_NW_WORKLOAD interface" corresponds to the SAP note 1053634 - SCSM_NW_WORKLOAD interface for reading ABAP statistics data - SAP for Me. In fact, it's the name of the function group containing the function modules which can be called to read the ABAP statistics data (data displayed by the transaction codes ST03, ST03N, STAT).

There are very few code snippets about these function modules, so I decided to publish a little test program which calls these function modules. This program is useful in debug to find out how the ABAP statistics data are structured, to build your own program with the data you need.

The program calls the following RFC-enabled function modules:

  • SWNC_GET_DIRECTORY_FRAME
  • SWNC_GET_AGGREGATES_FRAME
  • SWNC_GET_SNAPSHOT_FRAME
  • SWNC_GET_STATRECS_FRAME

It calls SWNC_GET_DIRECTORY_FRAME and SWNC_GET_AGGREGATES_FRAME to read the whole aggregated data (total and by server).

It calls SWNC_GET_SNAPSHOT_FRAME and SWNC_GET_STATRECS_FRAME to read the detailed records of ABAP statistics data of the last 3 days, with a time frame of 60 minutes (these filter and setting can be changed).

I used this program in an ABAP 7.40 SP 23 system.

Happy coding and feel free to publish your own code snippets!

Sandra

REPORT z_read_st03n_data.
* Note 1053634:
* With the SAP upgrade to SAP_BASIS 7.0(NW 2004s), both the methods and
* the corresponding function modules for reading ABAP statistics data
* have changed. The SAPWL_GLOB_STAT function group can no longer be
* used as of SAP_BASIS 7.0.
* (SAPWL_GLOB_STAT = SAPWL_STATREC_FROM_REMOTE_SYS, etc.)
* The new function group includes the following four function modules:
* - SWNC_GET_DIRECTORY_FRAME
* - SWNC_GET_AGGREGATES_FRAME
* - SWNC_GET_SNAPSHOT_FRAME
* - SWNC_GET_STATRECS_FRAME
DATA(select_from_systems) = VALUE swncgl_t_dest( ).
DATA(all_directories)  = VALUE swncgl_t_alldir( ).
DATA(protocol_allrcinf) = VALUE swncgl_t_allrcinf( ).

select_from_systems = VALUE #(
  ( select_system  = sy-sysid
*    select_servers =
) ).
CALL FUNCTION 'SWNC_GET_DIRECTORY_FRAME'
  EXPORTING
    select_from_systems = select_from_systems "sy-sysid
  IMPORTING
    all_directories     = all_directories
    protocol            = protocol_allrcinf.

DATA(select_system) = VALUE swncsysdest( ).
DATA(systemid) = VALUE swncsysid( ).
DATA(instance) = VALUE swnchostname( ).
DATA(periodtype) = VALUE swncperitype( ).
DATA(periodstrt) = VALUE swncdatum( ).
DATA(summary_only) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(tasktype) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggtasktype( ).
DATA(tasktimes) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggtasktimes( ).
DATA(times) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggtimes( ).
DATA(dbprocs) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggdbprocs( ).
DATA(extsystem) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggextsystem( ).
DATA(tcdet) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggtcdet( ).
DATA(frontend) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggfrontend( ).
DATA(memory) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggmemory( ).
DATA(spool) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggspool( ).
DATA(spoolact) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggspoolact( ).
DATA(tablerec) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggtablerec( ).
DATA(usertcode) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggusertcode( ).
DATA(userworkload) = VALUE swncgl_t_agguserworkload( ).
DATA(rfcclnt) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggrfcclnt( ).
DATA(rfcclntdest) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggrfcclntdest( ).
DATA(rfcsrvr) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggrfcsrvr( ).
DATA(rfcsrvrdest) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggrfcsrvrdest( ).
DATA(astat) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggappstat( ).
DATA(hitlist_database) = VALUE swncgl_t_hitlist( ).
DATA(hitlist_resptime) = VALUE swncgl_t_hitlist( ).
DATA(hitlist_astat_db) = VALUE swncgl_t_hitlistappl( ).
DATA(hitlist_astat_resptime) = VALUE swncgl_t_hitlistappl( ).
DATA(comp_hierarchy) = VALUE swncgl_t_comphiertxt( ).
DATA(org_units) = VALUE swncgl_t_orgunit( ).
DATA(dbcon) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggdbc( ).
DATA(webc) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggwebclnt( ).
DATA(webcd) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggwebdest( ).
DATA(webs) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggwebclnt( ).
DATA(websd) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggwebdest( ).
DATA(vmc) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggvmc( ).
DATA(protocol_rcinf) = VALUE swncgl_t_rcinf( ).
DATA(trex) = VALUE swncgl_t_aggtrex( ).

LOOP AT all_directories REFERENCE INTO DATA(directory).
  summary_only = abap_false.
  CALL FUNCTION 'SWNC_GET_AGGREGATES_FRAME'
    EXPORTING
*      select_system          = " RFC destination?
      systemid               = directory->assigndsys
      instance               = directory->component
      periodtype             = directory->periodtype
      periodstrt             = directory->periodstrt
      summary_only           = summary_only
    IMPORTING
      tasktype               = tasktype
      tasktimes              = tasktimes
      times                  = times
      dbprocs                = dbprocs
      extsystem              = extsystem
      tcdet                  = tcdet
      frontend               = frontend
      memory                 = memory
      spool                  = spool
      spoolact               = spoolact
      tablerec               = tablerec
      usertcode              = usertcode
      userworkload           = userworkload
      rfcclnt                = rfcclnt
      rfcclntdest            = rfcclntdest
      rfcsrvr                = rfcsrvr
      rfcsrvrdest            = rfcsrvrdest
      astat                  = astat
      hitlist_database       = hitlist_database
      hitlist_resptime       = hitlist_resptime
      hitlist_astat_db       = hitlist_astat_db
      hitlist_astat_resptime = hitlist_astat_resptime
      comp_hierarchy         = comp_hierarchy
      org_units              = org_units
      dbcon                  = dbcon
      webc                   = webc
      webcd                  = webcd
      webs                   = webs
      websd                  = websd
      vmc                    = vmc
      protocol               = protocol_rcinf
      trex                   = trex.
  ASSERT 1 = 1. " debug helper
ENDLOOP.

DATA(read_start_date) = VALUE swncdatum( ).
DATA(read_start_time) = VALUE swncuzeit( ).
DATA(read_end_date) = VALUE swncdatum( ).
DATA(read_end_time) = VALUE swncuzeit( ).
DATA(read_time_zone) = VALUE swnctimezone( ).
DATA(read_client) = VALUE swncmandt( ).
DATA(read_username) = VALUE swncuname( ).
DATA(flag_exclude_username) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(read_transids) = VALUE swncgl_t_transid( ).
DATA(read_workprocess) = VALUE swncrshrt( ).
DATA(read_only_mainrecords) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(read_stat) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(read_astat) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(wait_seconds) = VALUE i( ).
DATA(max_records) = VALUE swncrecs( ).
DATA(get_comp_hierarchy) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(get_org_units) = VALUE swnc_cflag( ).
DATA(all_statrecs) = VALUE swncgl_t_allrecs( ).
DATA(protocol) = VALUE swncgl_t_allrcinf( ).
DATA(ext_esi_records) = VALUE swncgl_t_esirecs( ).
DATA(ext_passport_records) = VALUE swncgl_t_passportrecs( ).
DATA(webservice_records) = VALUE swncgl_t_webservicerecs( ).
DATA(trex_records) = VALUE swncgl_t_trexrecs( ).

read_start_date = sy-datum - 3.
read_start_time = '000000'.
read_end_date = sy-datum.
read_end_time = sy-uzeit.
read_stat = abap_true.
*read_astat = abap_true.
max_records = -1.

data(time_resolution) = value swnctimeres( ).
data(tasktypes_per_workprocess) = value swnc_cflag( ).
data(tcodes_with_dynpro_number) = value swnc_cflag( ).
data(terminal_instead_of_username) = value swnc_cflag( ).
data(ashitl_database) = value swncgl_t_hitlistappl( ).
data(ashitl_resptime) = value swncgl_t_hitlistappl( ).

time_resolution = 60. "60 minutes

call function 'SWNC_GET_SNAPSHOT_FRAME'
  EXPORTING
*    select_system                = SPACE
*    select_server                =
*    read_time_zone               =
    read_start_date              = read_start_date
    read_start_time              = read_start_time
    read_end_date                = read_end_date
    read_end_time                = read_end_time
    read_client                  = read_client
    read_username                = read_username
    read_workprocess             = read_workprocess
    read_stat                    = read_stat
    read_astat                   = read_astat
    wait_seconds                 = wait_seconds
    time_resolution              = time_resolution
    tasktypes_per_workprocess    = tasktypes_per_workprocess
    tcodes_with_dynpro_number    = tcodes_with_dynpro_number
    terminal_instead_of_username = terminal_instead_of_username
    max_records                  = max_records
  IMPORTING
    tasktype                     = tasktype
    tasktimes                    = tasktimes
    times                        = times
    dbprocs                      = dbprocs
    extsystem                    = extsystem
    tcdet                        = tcdet
    frontend                     = frontend
    memory                       = memory
    spool                        = spool
    spoolact                     = spoolact
    tablerec                     = tablerec
    usertcode                    = usertcode
    userworkload                 = userworkload
    rfcclnt                      = rfcclnt
    rfcclntdest                  = rfcclntdest
    rfcsrvr                      = rfcsrvr
    rfcsrvrdest                  = rfcsrvrdest
    astat                        = astat
    hitlist_database             = hitlist_database
    hitlist_resptime             = hitlist_resptime
    ashitl_database              = ashitl_database
    ashitl_resptime              = ashitl_resptime
    comp_hierarchy               = comp_hierarchy
    org_units                    = org_units
    dbcon                        = dbcon
    webc                         = webc
    webcd                        = webcd
    webs                         = webs
    websd                        = websd
    vmc                          = vmc
    protocol                     = protocol.

CALL FUNCTION 'SWNC_GET_STATRECS_FRAME'
  EXPORTING
    select_from_systems   = select_from_systems
    read_start_date       = read_start_date
    read_start_time       = read_start_time
    read_end_date         = read_end_date
    read_end_time         = read_end_time
    read_time_zone        = read_time_zone
    read_client           = read_client
    read_username         = read_username
    flag_exclude_username = flag_exclude_username
    read_transids         = read_transids
    read_workprocess      = read_workprocess
    read_only_mainrecords = read_only_mainrecords
    read_stat             = read_stat
    read_astat            = read_astat
    wait_seconds          = wait_seconds
    max_records           = max_records
    get_comp_hierarchy    = get_comp_hierarchy
    get_org_units         = get_org_units
  IMPORTING
    all_statrecs          = all_statrecs
    protocol              = protocol
    ext_esi_records       = ext_esi_records
    ext_passport_records  = ext_passport_records
    webservice_records    = webservice_records
    trex_records          = trex_records.

LOOP AT all_statrecs REFERENCE INTO DATA(statrecs).
  LOOP AT statrecs->statrecs REFERENCE INTO DATA(statrec)
      WHERE mainrec-tcode IS NOT INITIAL.
    WRITE: / statrec->mainrec-account, statrec->mainrec-starttimestamp, statrec->mainrec-tcode.
  ENDLOOP.
ENDLOOP.
ASSERT 1 = 1. " debug helper

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytical Queries Previous Year
entry.content:
Good day @Rawel 

Thank you for your question

In summary, you can create restricted measures to show this year and last year side by side in Custom Analytical Queries but the app does not support deriving a second prompt value when you create it inside the query prompt. So, you cannot have a single Year input and automatically fill Previous Year as year minus 1 purely in the query. See Custom Analytical Queries and Services and Creating Analytical Queries for more insights.

Here is a step-by-step guide:

In your system, open Custom Analytical Queries, then open either your existing query or create a new one on your production data source.


Go to Field Selection and ensure you have your time characteristic available, either your Fiscal Year or Calendar Year, depending on your cube. (using an existing sample for reference in this case).

Go to Measures and create: Restricted Measure 1: Current Year Quantity, Restrict by year= Prompt (P_Year_Current) & Restricted Measure 2: Previous Year Quantity, Restrict by Year= Prompt (P_Year_Previous).

Then go to Display or Field Selection, put your dimensions (material, plant, etc.) in Rows and put the two restricted measures in columns.

Save and run the query.

If you only require one user input, then do it in Analytics Cloud. Embedded Custom Analytical Queries alone will not calculate previous year from the entered year.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Drive more Business Value out of your SAP Public Cloud Solution Subscriptions.
entry.content:
Hi Egbert,
 
The actual usage depends on the application. To simplify, let's focus on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and SAP S/4HANA on-premise.
 
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there isn't a report that shows your users per application. However, you can look at usage by Fiori App in several ways:
- In SAP for Me, you can view a Usage report that shows the most used SAP Fiori Apps for the customer.
- You can also perform user tracing using the App Display Authorization Trace to understand user usage.

 

- The Early Watch Report included in SAP for Me shows you the top apps used by application area and distinct users.

 

For SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, please refer to the following note: https://me.sap.com/notes/3203036/E 
 
For SAP S/4HANA on-premise systems, please refer to the following note: https://me.sap.com/notes/2629143/E 
 
Regarding your question about peer comparison, this is based on customers using the same solution within the same Mastercode (Industry), independent of the size of the customer.
 
Hope this helps,
Best regards,
Marco

entry.title: How to Take SAP’s New Performance-Based Certification Exams
entry.content:
Beginning in November 2025, SAP updated parts of its certification program by introducing scenario-based assessments exams. These exams replace the traditional proctored, multiple-choice format and are designed to better reflect real-world use cases.

In this post, I walk you through what has changed, how the new exam formats work, what to expect from AI-assisted and expert-reviewed assessments, and what this means for certification renewal—based on my own experience retaking the SAP BTP Solution Architect exam.

Some certifications are now available only through this new approach like:

With this new format, there is less focus on memorizing detailed information. Instead, candidates demonstrate their knowledge by solving practical scenarios. You may complete tasks using AI-assisted tools or submit video-based responses that are reviewed by SAP experts later.

 You can explore available certifications by logging into SAP Learning at https://learning.sap.com and navigating to the Get Certified section.

To identify the exam format, click on the exam you are interested in. On the above right side of the exam page, the presence of “Schedule Exam” indicates that the exam is delivered through a third-party proctoring service:

 

According to the SAP latest announcement, all SAP exams (by the end of March 2026) will be switched to this self-managed new performance-based exam.

If you choose the AI option with this new approach, the results are reviewed automatically in real time right after your submission. You can see your failure or success immediately. If you fail, you will receive the detailed analysis of your response by AI which can help you with your next exam try.

If you choose to submit videos, it will be scored by experts within 10 business days.

This analyzing session will not be available to you in your next log on, please make sure to review that before missing that session to help you to focus on your weakness for your next same exam try.

How real skills are used in scenario based

Practical

Certification exams mimic real tasks, such as configuring real SAP systems, building processes, coding, or delivering SAP solutions based on a case study.

Open book

Leverage all kinds of resources to complete the exams, just as you would on an actual SAP project. 

AI-enabled

Access AI support, such as SAP Joule for Consultants or any other AI Large Language Models (LLMs).

System-based assessment

Learners have the opportunity to complete practical tasks in time-limited SAP system simulations, testing their ability to perform specific tasks or operations.

Scenario-based assessment

Learners engage in time-limited role-play with an AI avatar, delivering SAP solutions, advising on architecture, and performing simulations.

A subscription to SAP Learning Hub includes 4 SAP certification exam attempts in one year or you can buy certification attempts (LINK).

At the time of writing this blog, to renew a certification for an additional year, you must have an active SAP Learning Hub subscription to complete the required renewal assessment:

If your certification is still valid, the renewal process does not require taking a performance-based or scenario-based exam. This exam formats apply only when pursuing a new certification, provided that the certification has already transitioned to the new scenario-based or practical exam approach.

Recently I decided to retake SAP BTP Solution Architect rather than renew through leaning Hub assessment to help me to write this post.

Here I walk you through high level steps:

First, you find your desired Exam page and click on the link:

https://learning.sap.com/certifications/sap-certified-professional-solution-architect-sap-btp

Next you choose “Go to Certification Exam”:

Then, you see the screen below and after clicking the box for “Terms and Conditions” you can hit “start Certification Exam” that will use one of your exam attempts credits and you have 24 hours to do the exam, or you lose one of your exams attempts credits:

As shown above, you have up to four exam attempts within a one-year period to achieve certification. If all four attempts are unsuccessful, you must wait 12 months before retaking the same exam.

Next, you will see the page below, which I chose AI for my Role-play then click on “Agree and get Started”:

Then you see the next screen and after allowing your camera, you will be able to start the exam by clicking on Start button:

Important note: Once you start the exam session, the assessment typically takes around 20–30 minutes and is conducted through an AI-powered chat experience using Yoodli technology. Before clicking on Start button, it is strongly recommended that you thoroughly review the case study PDF provided as part of the exam and prepare your solution in advance, for example in a notepad or word document, which you can reference during the AI role-play conversation.

This exam uses Yoodli technology and does not require any software installation. If you would like to familiarize yourself with the format, you can create a free account at https://yoodli.ai/ and practice using sample role-play scenarios.

During the exam, an interactive chat window will appear, allowing you to follow the conversation and view a live transcript of the AI avatar’s responses.

Areas Where There Is Still Room for Improvement

While this new exam approach is a positive step forward, there are still areas that could benefit from further refinement. In particular, it would help to ensure that participants clearly understand the scenario or practice environment and easily find sufficient time to review the requirements and prepare their responses before starting the session.

Compared to traditional proctored exams, there are also open questions around identity verification. It is not yet clear how this new format consistently confirms that the individual completing the assessment is the same person who registered for the exam.

In addition, with the new exam approach, candidates do not currently receive an automatic email notification showing pass or fail status, scores, or a detailed performance analysis.

Hopefully, the SAP certification team will continue to enhance this model so that it aligns more closely with traditional proctored exams in these areas

Reference links:

Reimagining certification in the age of AI
Step-by-step guide - How to cancel your existing booking for a certification exam?

 Share with others and Connect with us!

Please leave your comment if you have anything to add!
If you would like to ask questions, please use the community Q&A.
Give us a like and share on social media if you feel it was useful!
You can check my posts and follow me in People SAP @Amin_Omidy 

Thanks, and wish you a happy reading!

@ManoelCosta @marcobarat

entry.title: Ledger in Management Accounting in S/4HANA public cloud
entry.content:
In this blog we will explain the impact of the Universal Journal’s ledger concept on controlling/ cost management. In particular the options for parallel valuation including universal parallel accounting (UPA) and the group valuation ledger. Addiiotnal we will explain the usage of extension ledgers for management purposes.

enjoy
Birgit Öttinger and  Stefan Walz

 

The Universal Journal - Basics

The Universal Journal is for sure the key innovation driver for accounting and controlling in S/4HANA. The integration of Legal and Management Reporting allows a drastic simplification in management accounting, reduces period-end activities, and at the same time enables new functionalities and completely new, fascinating reporting insights. As an example, you can check out the new project accounting and service management functionality

Figure1: Universal Journal - Integration of accounting applications

The Universal Journal offers a comprehensive perspective on your external accounting through General Ledger Accounting. Furthermore, it facilitates Management Reporting and Controlling. Management Reporting and Controlling, Market segment reporting (margin analysis), profit center and revenue recognition data are seamlessly integrated with General Ledger Accounting and consolidated into a single source of truth: the Universal Journal.

Parallel Accounting utilizing Parallel Ledgers

With the Universal Journal, parallel ledgers are available to calculate and store different amounts for financial transactions according to various accounting principles, such as IFRS (International Financial Reporting Standards) and local GAAP

One example is event-based revenue recognition using a cost based POC method in the IFRS ledger and a completed contract method in the local ledger.

In public cloud in the past, parallel valuation for cost management was limited in the sense that cost management only worked with one valuation approach: the value from the leading ledger was adopted for all parallel standard ledgers. With Universal Parallel Accounting parallel valuation in cost management, asset management, and materials management is possible: the values can be defined per ledger. UPA is always active in SAP Cloud ERP (public edition) and can be activated in SAP Cloud ERP Private (on premise) using a business function.

Here some examples for different valuation per ledger, which have an impact on controlling/ cost management:

  • You can define ledger-dependent cost rates for time confirmation and activities.
  • Controlling allocations like universal allocation, settlement or overhead calculation take the posted amounts per ledger into account. For example, there can be different asset depreciation expenses per ledger posted on a cost center. The subsequent cost center allocation allocates different amounts per ledger, ensuring that the cost center balances to zero in all ledgers.
  • You can maintain settlement rules that are ledger dependent. For example, in ledger A, you can activate the costs and settle to fixed asset—while in ledger B, you cannot activate, and instead, you settle to a cost center.
  • In the material ledger, you can maintain ledger-dependent material prices, which lead to different costs of goods sold (COGS) or material consumption costs per ledger.

This ledger-dependent valuation enables you to get a parallel value flow per ledger.

 An additional advantage of universal parallel accounting: It supports different fiscal year variants within one controlling area or even for one company code. Without universal parallel accounting, the customer is forced to define multiple controlling areas if different fiscal year variants are needed. This significantly restricts the group value flow.

Note: All fiscal year variants used need to have identic start and end dates (e.g. a fiscal period is always equal to a month).

It is not possible to create new additional ledgers for existing company codes. You cannot add or remove ledgers after scoping is completed.  All standard ledgers must be fixed before go live.

It is not recommended to proactively activate an additional ledger to cover special reporting requirements and do not take care of this parallel ledger. E.g. do not regularly perform closing. You need to close the period in all standard ledgers.

The leading ledger

One ledger must be defined as leading ledger.
SAP delivers as default the leading ledger 0L. This ledger is assigned to all company codes.

In the leading ledger all company codes must use the same fiscal year variant.

Only the leading ledger is known in logistic applications.
Examples:

  • T&E project billing reads only from leading ledger
  • cost and revenue reporting in CPM and service management read from leading ledger only
  • plan data for service orders and projects is only updated in the leading ledger

The leading ledger is the base for consolidation/ group reporting.

 

The extension ledger

With the integration of legal and management reporting, many innovations and new reporting insights are possible, but new approaches are needed to account for management-specific assessments and management specific data. For example, the representation for alternative and additional costs, or commitments and order entry data.

For this purpose, we introduced the extension ledger. Extension ledgers store management accounting data only and have no impact on legal reporting.
An extension ledger must be assigned to a standard ledger: while the standard ledger contains journal entries for all business transactions for legal and management accounting purposes, the extension ledger contains management accounting relevant journal entries only. The extension ledger only stores delta entries to the underlying standard ledger. This setup assumes that all postings in the underlying standard ledger are part of the extension ledger reporting. With this redundant data storage is avoided.

Two different ledger types are available for extension ledgers:

  • The management accounting ledger, which is used to post additional costs like statistical sales conditions and manual adjustment postings. In public cloud ledger 0C is created by default. Examples can be found in the following blog post: margin analysis 4 Sell from stock
  • The commitment ledger is used to update e.g., order entries or purchase order commitments. In public cloud ledger 0E is created by default.

You can post management adjustments directly in the management accounting extension ledger 0C with no update in a legal standard ledger as these postings are not relevant for legal reporting.
When you run a report for an extension ledger, the journal entries of the extension ledger and the underlying standard ledger are always displayed aggregated.

In public cloud default setup, extension ledgers are assigned to the leading ledger
-> 0E / 0C delivered via best practice content
A SSCUI allows customers to create additional extension ledgers assigned to any underlying ledger (SSCUI: Define Extension Ledger (103265))

Ledger setup from controlling perspective

The conditions above could lead to the following ledger setup:

Figure 2: ledger setup example

The leading ledger is equal in all company codes. It uses the same accounting principle (IFRS), and the same fiscal year variant (K4). The EBRR method for customer projects is defined as cost-based POC.
The extension ledgers 0E and 0C are assigned to the leading ledger 0L. With this setup, management reporting is mainly done in the leading ledger 0L.
The parallel ledger 2L is differently configured for both company codes: there are different local GAAPs and fiscal year variants assigned. Based on the different accounting principles assigned, different revenue recognition methods could be used for customer projects.

SAP recommends – in deviation to the delivered standard configuration - to use the leading ledger with a corporate accounting principle and one of the non-leading ledgers for the local accounting principle.

 

To enable controlling across multiple companies, you should consider the leading ledger as the main ledger for management reporting because of the following reasons:

  • The leading ledger uses the same valuation approach across all company codes. Recommendation is to assign the corporate accounting principle (typically IFRS or USGAAP).
  • Additionally, the leading ledger should use the same fiscal year variant (FYV) for all company codes, this simplifies company code comparisons.
  • Extension ledgers are assigned to the leading ledger.
  • Plan data for logistic objects like service documents or projects is only updated in the leading ledger.
  • Some revenue recognition functionality and URR is per default only active for IFRS or USGAAP – like e.g. revenue allocation between performance obligations. You will not allocate revenue in a local GAAP like HGB! This has impact on tax calculations.
    Our assumption is, that revenue allocation should impact margin analysis. Thus, management accounting should be done with IFRS/ USGAAP accounting principles, if revenue allocation is used.
    Example for revenue allocation: you sell a mobile for 1€ together with a 24 month contract. The standalone selling price is 1000€. IFRS revenue allocation would allocate revenue from the contract to the mobile. Therefore, the realized revenue for the mobile would be higher than the 1€ billed.

If more than one ledger is used, country specific accounting principles shall be assigned to a non-leading ledger (in this case the standard settings deployed during scope must be changed > ledger switch). With this, the accounting principles assigned in the non-leading ledger can be different for different company codes. Alternative FYV can be assigned per company code.

 This also aligns with the guidance from legal perspective - see here

  • SAP help Ledger Scenarios: Choosing the Right Combination for Your Business Needs 
  • KBA Assigning Accounting Principles to Ledgers and Company Codes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 
  • community article ledger-configuration 

Group Valuation Ledger

 Purpose

The group valuation ledger aims to eliminate profit and margins for intercompany processes on transaction level. With this, intercompany processes are evaluated on a cost only basis. This enables basic functionality for market segment reporting from a group perspective. Especially group costs for multi-step production processes in several company codes can be analyzed.

It is not recommended to use the group valuation ledger as a basis for consolidation. Consolidation should be based on the leading ledger.

 

Technical Conditions

The Group Valuation ledger 4G in public cloud, can only be added during initial scoping with scope item 5W2, a deletion is not supported.

The supported scope is listed in the SAP note 3100892 and SAP note 3093830 and will be activated with the activation of the scope item.

It is recommended to use the same accounting principle in 4G and in the leading ledger. The group ledger should be referenced to the leading ledger – one ledger group.

Closing must run in 4G as in all standard ledgers.

supported scope with CE 2602

First focus was on intercompany stock transfer scenarios. As mentioned in note 3100892 not all intercompany stock transfer scenarios are supported with ledger 4G. E.g. returns, sales BOMs, and subcontracting are not supported.

Intercompany sales processes and especially intercompany service processes do not support a proper group view (no revenue and margin elimination).

For intercompany activity allocations/ time confirmations the intercompany margin is not posted in the group valuation ledger.

 

Different approaches for group reporting and group valuation ledger

Although group valuation ledger and group reporting ultimately serve consolidation purposes, there are differences:

Group valuation ledger (Ledger 4G) targets a real-time, transaction-based management perspective by eliminating intercompany profits between individual trading partners. Supporting management decisions along the end-to-end value chain – for one special ICO sales process only, whereas

Group reporting is used to fulfill the legally required consolidation process including the period-end closing according to the relevant accounting standard. For this in group reporting a separate consolidation ledger for all closing and reporting steps is used.

entry.title: User validation error due to mandatory Event Reason for Job Information from the 2H 2025 release.
entry.content:
Hello team,

As you know, starting with the 2H 2025 Release, the Event Reason field is now mandatory for the ONB-RCM integration. If it is not mapped, this change will trigger a business process error, preventing the candidate from moving from ONB to RCM
 
There are several blogs and KBAs that explain how to address/prevent this issue, either by creating a business rule or by using the Recruit-to-Hire Data Mapping tool (0003205529, 3232848, 0003671856 ). 
 
After analyzing the available options, we decided to map it using the Recruit-to-Hire Data Mapping tool. However, even after implementing this solution, we are still facing issues in our test environment, so I hope someone here can help us address them.
 
As mentioned in the notes I shared earlier, I created a custom picklist field in each existing job requisition, using external code values identical to the existing hire event external codes in EC.
Event reason custom field in job requisition
 
 

Matching picklist used for job requisition custom field

Then, I mapped the corresponding field in JobInfo

 

After doing all that, it is supposed to fix the mandatory event reason issue but we keep getting the following error:

I got a JSON Output response to check the values passed from recruiting to onboarding and it looks like this 

 
It seems that the event reason value is being passed correctly; however, even after restarting the process from BPE, the issue persists. As a result, the onboardee remains stuck with a data validation error and does not appear in the ONB dashboard

 For context:

  1. I have tested with multiple candidates in different job Reqs and the behavior is the same, 
  2. The event-reason standard field wasn't created in manage business configuration so I created it recently (I don't know how ONB worked before that)
I’m sharing my experience with this configuration to get any suggestions, as I honestly don’t understand what’s happening here

I already opened a SAP Support ticket, if I receive a solution or an explication, I'll share it later.

entry.title: Re: Impact of Employee Central on Performance and Goals M...
entry.content:
Based on my experience with SAP SuccessFactors, here are some key points and potential impacts to consider when introducing Employee Central (EC) alongside an existing Talent suite:

  1. Job Structure

    • With EC, the Job Codes /Job Classifications will likely become the master data for your Talent processes. Any misalignment between EC and the Talent module can impact competencies

    • It’s important to review mappings between EC Job Codes and competencies ( and maybe Skills) to ensure that performance, succession, and development plans functions correctly.

  2. Position Management

    • If you are using positions  EC will now control the position hierarchy. Vacant manager positions can affect routemaps, talent reviews.

    • Validate that position hierarchies are correct in EC and check for any changes in reporting lines that could affect talent processes, for example if the position of a manager becomes empty what will happen to performance forms (?).

  3. Job Relationships and Performance Route Maps

    • Talent modules often rely on job relationships for routing and notifications.

    • With EC, these relationships may be updated automatically via position , which could change existing performance route maps or calibration groupings. It’s important to test all routing scenarios before going live.

  4. Additional considerations

    • Ensure integration points (data sync, replication to Talent modules) are tested thoroughly.

    • Review defaulting rules in Performance, Succession, and Career modules, as they may pull new EC data differently.

Bottom line: EC becomes the master for core HR data, so the main impact will be around how Talent modules read job, position, and reporting information.
Thorough testing of route maps, calibration groups, and competency mappings is critical to avoid disruption.

entry.title: SAP for Me – Adoption Report – Drive More Business Value Realization
entry.content:
This blog is a continuation of my previous blog, Drive more Business Value out of your SAP Public Cloud Solution Subscriptions.

However, in this blog, I want to focus on the Adoption Report included in SAP for Me – Customer Insights as a quick way to understand opportunities for Business Value Realization.

But first, I would like to refer you to the blog SAP Adoption PDF Report generator in Customer Insights (in SAP for Me), written by my SAP colleague Jose Seren, to understand the overall report structure.

Now, similar to my previous blog, if you are an SAP Public Cloud customer running solutions like SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, etc., or you are a new SAP Business Suite customer running public cloud packages, this report can help you to understand areas of unrealized business value in your integrated system landscape.

While the report is very comprehensive, I only would like to focus on the Business Value Realization section, because it is here where you can see quick wins on value realization by focusing on value drivers for which you currently have no solution capabilities in use or low usage.

Let's look at the following example.

Business Value Realization Overview by Solution Area

In this example, this SAP customer is running several public cloud solutions including SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors (Core HR and Payroll, Learning and Talent), SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, several SAP Procurement solutions (Ariba Buying and Invoicing, Ariba Sourcing, Ariba Central Invoice Management, etc.), and some SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition add-ons like Cash & Treasury, Multi-Bank Connectivity, and Group Reporting.

Now, the graphic below shows the total number of value drivers that have solution capabilities in use per solution area. For instance, if I look at SAP Business Data Cloud, the report indicates that out of 10 value drivers our customer is only using solution capabilities that impact 5 value drivers—so this means that there are great opportunities to bring more business value to this solution and impact the other 5 value drivers.

Business Value Realization Overview by Solution Area – Value Drivers with used and unused solution capabilities

Now, if we drill down in the report for SAP Business Data Cloud, the report presents to me the value drivers that currently have unused solution capabilities, which I can analyze to bring more business value to this solution area.

Detailed Business Value Realization – Business Data Cloud - Value Drivers with used and unused solution capabilities

As you can see from the report, I have an opportunity to start using solution capabilities that can impact these five value drivers.

Let me focus on the value driver “Reduce data management cost” in SAP Business Data Cloud—the report itself includes the solution capabilities that I can start activating to bring more business value. You can find them at the end of the Adoption Report under “Unrealized Business Value by Solution Area.”

Unrealized Business Value – Value drivers that can impact business outcomes by activating solution capability not used

As you can see from the graphic, the customer could activate “Analytics Cataloging” solution capability to impact the value driver “reduce data management cost.” However, you can see that this solution capability will also impact other value drivers, including increase user confidence in data and improve analytics FTE productivity.

Unrealized Business Value – Value drivers that can impact business outcomes by activating solution capability not used

As you can see from the graphic, the customer could activate “Story Extensibility” solution capability to impact the value driver “reduce data management cost.” However, you can see that this solution capability will also impact other value drivers, including: reduce data integration cost and improve analytics FTE productivity.

As you can see, the report provides a very fast overview of unrealized business value. Alternatively to the report, and to explore the value drivers, solution capabilities, and opportunities to realize more business value, you can use the Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value section in SAP for Me, as I explained in my previous blog.

SAP for Me - Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value

I hope this Adoption Report included in SAP for Me provides you with some ideas to bring more business outcomes for your entire public cloud landscape.

Keep in mind that solution capabilities are expanding from traditional functional scope to also include SAP Business AI, so SAP will continue to add more in this area.

Remember, this is not the only tool that can be used; SAP has other tools such as SAP Signavio, SAP WalkMe, SAP LeanIX, and SAP Cloud ALM that can be used in tandem to help drive more business value from your SAP subscription. I encourage you to discuss these points with your SAP Customer Success Manager, SAP Account Executive, or SAP Partner. They may be able to provide you with additional recommendations and guidance.

Your insights and opinions are valuable, so please don't hesitate to contribute by commenting on this blog.

Follow us via @SAP and #S4HANA or follow @Marco_Valencia (SAP Business Suite Customer Success Management).

entry.title: Re: Programmatically create and retrieve documents attached in GOS (Generic Object Services) via Sto
entry.content:
Excellent and very useful blog, thanks for sharing 👍

Just to add for readers:
• GOS attachments are typically stored via ArchiveLink and linked using SRGBTBREL (RELTYPE = ‘ATTA’)
• ARCHIVOBJECT_CREATE_FILE can work with presentation server or application server paths, but logical file names (e.g. ARCHIVLINK_FILE_READ) must be properly maintained via FILE transaction
• For background jobs or UI5 scenarios, converting content using SCMS_BINARY_TO_XSTRING and handling files on the app server is the recommended approach

This approach works well for ECC as well as S/4HANA systems using content servers like SAP Content Server or OpenText.

entry.title: Re: From GOS attachment to generate spool or pdf
entry.content:
The issue is conceptual rather than technical.

OTF_TO_PDF can only convert OTF data (output generated by SAPscript / SmartForms / SAP Spool).
A GOS attachment is not OTF, it is already a stored binary document (PDF, DOCX, XLS, JPG, etc.).

That is why you get the error “OTF command ‘//’ endpoint missing” — you are passing non‑OTF binary data to OTF_TO_PDF.

Important clarification

  • GOS attachments uploaded from presentation server are stored via ArchiveLink / Content Server

  • They are not spool requests

  • OTF_TO_PDF must not be used for generic attachments

What you should do instead

Case 1: Attachment is already a PDF

  • Retrieve it using:

    • ARCHIVOBJECT_GET_TABLE or

    • SO_DOCUMENT_READ_API1

  • Convert SOLIX → XSTRING

  • Directly:

    • Download it

    • Display it

    • Attach it to email
      ✅ No conversion required

Case 2: You need a Spool
You cannot create a spool from an arbitrary attachment unless:

  • The attachment was originally generated by SAP (SmartForm / SAPscript)

Spool creation is only possible from:

  • SmartForm

  • SAPscript

  • Adobe Form

  • ABAP list output

Case 3: Attachment is DOC / XLS / IMG
SAP does not provide any standard FM to convert these to PDF.
Options:

  • Use an external converter (OpenText, Adobe, PDFLib, etc.)

  • Or store/display the original file as-is

Summary

  • OTF_TO_PDF ❌ cannot be used for GOS attachments

  • GOS attachments ≠ Spool output

  • If already PDF → just retrieve and display/download

  • Conversion to PDF requires external tools unless SAP-generated output

Hope this clarifies the limitation and correct approach.

entry.title: Re: Invoice attachment to R/3 system
entry.content: This is correct as per standard SRM → ECC design. Attachments added in SRM invoices are not transferred via IDoc to the backend FI document. As a workaround, customers usually: • Store attachments in a shared ArchiveLink repository accessible by both systems, or • Reattach documents in ECC via GOS, or • Build a custom solution using ArchiveLink APIs / middleware to replicate attachments (not SAP standard). There is no standard SAP note enabling SRM invoice attachments to appear automatically in FB03.

entry.title: Re: Problem in archivelink
entry.content:
This issue is not a functional GOS problem but a classic ArchiveLink / OpenText repository mismatch caused by repository or document type changes.

Based on your description, the most likely root causes are:

  1. Content Repository Change

    • You already observed that the content repository in TOA01 was changed.

    • Old documents are still physically stored in the old OpenText repository, but SAP now tries to open them via the new repository, so:

      • Documents no longer open directly

      • SAP forces download/export

      • File names and metadata are missing

  2. Missing or Incorrect MIME / Viewer Mapping

    • When documents open only after export, it usually means:

      • Viewer assignment is broken

      • MIME type is not correctly recognized

    • Check:

      • OAC3 → Document type → “Display in SAP GUI”

      • OAC0 / OAC2 → Viewer assignment for PDF

      • OAER / OAA3 (depending on release)

  3. Document Type Change (Z**PDF → Z**PFR)

    • Even if descriptions look the same, technical settings may differ

    • Compare both document types in OAC3:

      • MIME type

      • Viewer

      • “Original application”

      • Display behavior

  4. Old Repository Not Reachable

    • The error “document archived” strongly indicates:

      • Old OpenText repository is offline / decommissioned

      • RFC destination or HTTP destination no longer exists

    • BASIS must verify:

      • OpenText repository connectivity

      • ArchiveLink RFCs

      • Repository still mounted on OpenText side

entry.title: Re: API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV - Attach PDF document to Supplier Invoice
entry.content: This is a known limitation with the CPI OData adapter, which only supports JSON/ATOM payloads. For binary PDF uploads to API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV, the correct approach is to use the HTTP adapter, fetch the x-csrf-token first, and then POST the raw binary payload with proper headers (Content-Type: application/pdf). This matches how Postman works and avoids CPI payload transformation issues.

entry.title: Re: Added attachments via API to a supplier invoice are not visible
entry.content: Good clarification. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, supplier invoice attachments via API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV are supported only from release 1811 onward using communication arrangement SAP_COM_0057. Also important: when calling the API, the LinkedSAPObjectKey must be passed without the slash (InvoiceNumber + FiscalYear concatenated), otherwise attachments won’t appear in the UI. Enabling HDM (Harmonized Document Management) and maintaining the URL allowlist are mandatory steps as well.

entry.title: Re: Retention Period of PDF Attachments (on Journal Entri...
entry.content: To add one clarification: In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, attachment retention is driven by the business document lifecycle and legal retention rules, not by storage quota. SAP does not automatically delete PDF attachments (Journal Entries / Supplier Invoices) as long as the underlying business document exists and is not archived or deleted via Data Retention Management (DRM). Storage capacity (GB/TB) is a licensing topic and can be extended, but it does not impact audit retention. Auditors can always retrieve attachments electronically within the retention period—no printing required.

entry.title: Re: How can ı block Storage location
entry.content:
Did you mean you want to block storage location for some users ? 

SPRO > Materials Management > Inventory Management > Authorization Management > Authorization check for storage locations.  Activate the authoriztion check for storage location you want to block

In PFCG, restrict the users who can do transactions in this storage location.

 

If you want to block storage location for all users (do not want to use storage location for any future postings):

1) You can use authorizations solution to remove auth for all users in the storage location

2) Change the name of storage location and add prefix "Do not use" --> This will not block but users will not use

3) Use MM06 to mark deletion flag for all materials of this storage location. Also make     M7-127 message as error in configuring messages. Suggest to move all stocks to other storage locations before doing this.

entry.title: Re: regarding Invoice document attachment -VF03
entry.content:
In VF03, attachments shown under System → Services for Object (GOS) → Attachment List are not created automatically by default.

There are two possible ways attachments appear:

  1. Manual GOS attachment
    A user manually attaches a document (PDF, note, etc.) via GOS.
    In this case, the attachment list is enabled only for those billing documents where a user added an attachment.

  2. Automatic attachment via output (ArchiveLink)
    If invoice output (e.g. SmartForm/Adobe) is configured with ArchiveLink, the PDF is automatically stored in the content repository when the output is generated.
    This requires:

    • ArchiveLink configuration (OAC0 / OAC3)

    • Output type configured to store document

    • Content repository assignment to billing document (BUS2037)

If neither manual GOS attachment nor ArchiveLink output is configured, the Attachment List icon will not be active in VF03.

There is no mandatory setting that forces attachments for all invoices.

entry.title: Re: CDS-View for Attachment in Supplier Invoices
entry.content: In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, attachment metadata for Supplier Invoices is not exposed via CDS views. Standard approach is to use API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV (e.g. GetAllOriginals / GetAttachmentCount) to retrieve attachment details. CDS views can only be used if attachments are created as Document Info Records (DIR); otherwise, attachment access is API-only by design.

entry.title: Re: App for download attachments invoices in mass
entry.content:
In standard SAP (including S/4HANA Cloud), there is no delivered app that allows mass download of invoice attachments out-of-the-box.

Available options:

  • SAP API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV can be used to programmatically retrieve attachments in bulk (recommended approach).

  • Build a custom app or automation (Fiori / BTP / CPI / ABAP report) that:

    • Reads invoice numbers

    • Fetches attachments via API

    • Downloads them in mass (ZIP or structured folders)

  • For on‑premise systems, customers often use:

    • Custom ABAP reports using ArchiveLink (TOA01 / SOOD / SOFFCONT1)

    • DMS-based extraction if attachments are linked to DIRs

Conclusion:
Mass download of invoice attachments requires custom development or API-based automation; it is not supported by a standard SAP app.

entry.title: Re: Report RSBCS_REORG and KPRO ?
entry.content: “‘Deleted from KPRO’ refers to the physical deletion of SAPoffice document content stored in the Knowledge Provider (KPRO) repositories (e.g. attachments, binary content). ‘Deleted Address References’ indicates cleanup of obsolete SAPoffice recipient/address entries (e.g. user, distribution list references) linked to the deleted documents. Both are standard housekeeping actions performed by RSBCS_REORG to keep SAPoffice and workflow data consistent.”

entry.title: Re: RSBCS_REORG still does not delete anything
entry.content: RSBCS_REORG will not delete SAPoffice documents that are still referenced (e.g. in folders, workflows, or via KPRO). Please check: • Documents are not in private/shared folders (SOOD/SOOS) • No active references in workflows or business objects • Retention time parameters and authorization • Run SOST / workflow cleanup reports first SAP Notes on SAPoffice reorganization also explain these limitations.

entry.title: Re: RSBCS_REORG report spending much time over SOOD table
entry.content:
RSBCS_REORG performance issues on SOOD are usually caused by very large data volume and inefficient access paths chosen by the DB optimizer. Even with good stats and indexes, deleting very small date ranges (e.g. 1 day) can force index usage and lead to slow row-by-row deletes.

Recommendations:
• Run RSBCS_REORG in larger date ranges (weekly/monthly) instead of daily
• Execute during low system load and consider background jobs with smaller packages
• Check if KPRO / content server documents are involved, as this increases runtime
• On some DBs, disabling indexes temporarily or using DB-specific delete optimizations helps
• Ensure related cleanup reports (RSBCS_REORG_DEL, RSSO_DELETE_*) are executed in correct sequence

This behavior is known for SAPoffice tables (SOOD/SOOS/SOC3) with many years of data.

entry.title: Re: Strategic Decision Paths for Managing Hazardous Substances: SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA Migration

Product Compliance in S/4HANA does not fully replace classic HSM functionality from ECC; hazardous substance–related warehouse checks are mainly covered under EHS (new) and its integration with EWM. entry.title: Re: Raw material from international vendor to Finished go...
entry.content:
Hi, 

As per understanding your question,

RM from international vendor > sent to External Manufacturer via Plant 1025 (CC1106) > FG received directly at Plant 1800 (CC1100):

  1. Create PO for Raw Material (International Vendor)

ME21N: PO with Plant = 1025, storage location as per process, Incoterms, etc.

  1. Post Import Goods Receipt of Raw Material at Plant 1025

MIGO (GR for PO): Post GR to 1025 (stock available for issue to subcontractor).

  1. Create Subcontracting / External Processing PO for Finished Goods

ME21N: PO to External Manufacturer (Subcontractor)

Item: Finished Good material with Item Category = L (Subcontracting)

Maintain Component list (raw materials/packing if applicable) in PO (or via BOM).

  1. Create Delivery / Issue Components to Subcontractor from Plant 1025

MIGO: Transfer Posting O (Issue components to subcontractor) Stock moves from Plant 1025 to Subcontractor stock (Special stock O)

  1. Subcontractor Manufactures Finished Goods

Physical manufacturing happens at vendor site (no SAP production order needed unless you use advanced integration).

Post Subcontracting Goods Receipt of Finished Goods directly into Plant 1800

  1. MIGO (GR for Subcontracting PO) with Plant = 1800  Receive FG directly into Plant 1800 stock, and system consumes components from vendor stock automatically (based on consumption quantity).

Invoice Verification

  1. MIRO: Post vendor invoice (service/processing charges + any agreed components variance handling).
  2. Stock / Account Verification

Check stock and movements:

MB51 / ME2L, ME23N History, MMBE for stock.

Regards

entry.title: Re: Question: Delivery-cost condition error during Servic...
entry.content:
Delivery cost conditions are primarily designed for logistics processes involving goods receipt, freight, and transportation costs. In material POs, these conditions integrate naturally with GR and invoice verification. However, in service POs, the system processes costs differently because there is no physical delivery or freight component. This mismatch can sometimes trigger errors during Service Entry Sheet (SES) creation if the pricing procedure still expects delivery-related conditions.

Even if the condition is manual and has no records, the system may still treat it as relevant during SES processing if the condition type is flagged as mandatory in the pricing schema, the calculation schema is applied uniformly to both material and service POs without differentiation and the condition category is set in a way that makes it applicable to services, which can cause validation checks during SES posting.

SAP generally expects delivery cost conditions to be excluded from service scenarios, since services do not involve freight or delivery. If the same PO document type and pricing schema are used for both materials and services, the system cannot distinguish automatically. This is why configuration adjustments are often required.

To fix this

  • Use different calculation schemas for material vs. service POs, excluding delivery cost conditions from the service schema.
  • Review the condition type in transaction M/06 and ensure it is not marked as mandatory for service-related schemas.
  • Check schema determination rules (via M/08) to ensure service POs do not inherit delivery cost conditions unnecessarily.
  • Sometimes, conditions behave differently depending on account assignment. Verify if the SES error is linked to account assignment validation.

entry.title: Re: FREIGHT COST (Planned Delivery costs)
entry.content:
Why the issue occurs is because, planned Delivery Costs in SAP are tied to the PO header and linked to a single freight vendor. When you post partial goods receipts, the system distributes the planned delivery costs proportionally. At invoice posting (MIRO), SAP expects the invoicing party to match the freight vendor defined in the PO. If a different freight vendor is used for subsequent deliveries, the system throws the “Invoicing Party is different” error because the PO does not allow multiple freight vendors for planned delivery costs.

Below are the SAP Best Practices for International Procurement

Use Unplanned Delivery Costs
Instead of fixing freight vendor and costs at PO level, post freight invoices as unplanned delivery costs during MIRO. This allows you to enter different freight vendors and amounts per invoice without PO dependency. The costs are distributed to the PO items automatically.

Separate Freight POs (Service POs)
Create a service PO for freight services per shipment. Each freight forwarder is represented as a separate PO with its own vendor. This keeps the material PO clean and allows flexibility in handling multiple freight vendors.

Use Condition Types for Freight (Delivery Costs)
Configure freight condition types as non‑mandatory and allow manual entry at invoice level. This way, you can adjust freight charges per delivery without system errors.

Split Invoices by Vendor
Post material supplier invoices separately from freight supplier invoices. Each freight invoice can be posted against the PO with unplanned delivery costs or against a dedicated freight PO.

entry.title: Re: Raw material from international vendor to Finished go...
entry.content:
Here is a different way to structure the same business requirement in SAP ECC, using an alternative but still standard approach. You can model the flow with stock transfers and cross‑company processes. This gives you more control over valuation and accounting between company codes.

Raw Material Procurement (International Vendor → Plant 1025, CC1106)
ME21N: Create a standard PO for raw materials with plant = 1025.
MIGO: Post GR into plant 1025. Raw materials are now available in CC1106.

2. Transfer Raw Materials to Subcontractor
ME21N: Create a stock transport order (STO) or use subcontracting PO depending on setup.
MIGO: Issue raw materials to subcontractor (movement type 541).
Stock moves into special stock O at subcontractor, still owned by plant 1025.

3. Finished Goods Receipt into Plant 1025 (Optional Step)
If you want to keep the subcontracting cycle consistent, you can first post the finished goods receipt back into plant 1025 (movement type 101 for subcontracting PO). This consumes the raw materials from subcontractor stock and creates FG stock in plant 1025.

4. Cross‑Company Stock Transfer (Plant 1025 → Plant 1800)
ME21N: Create a stock transport order between plant 1025 (CC1106) and plant 1800 (CC1100).
VL10B / VL10D: Create outbound delivery from plant 1025.
VL02N: Post goods issue (movement type 351).
MIGO: Post goods receipt in plant 1800 (movement type 101).

This ensures proper intercompany billing between CC1106 and CC1100 if required.

5. Invoice Verification
MIRO: Post invoice for the subcontractor (processing charges).
Intercompany Billing: If STO is intercompany, create billing document in SD (VF01) and post invoice to CC1100.

This ensures correct financial postings between company codes.

entry.title: Re: MRP-RUN : STR ( stock transfer requisition) cansidred...
entry.content:
Why this happens is because, Planned order in 1003 → converted to STR (PR with doc type for stock transfer). MRP in 1008 sees the requirement element (planned order/STR) regardless of release status. Release strategy in MM controls whether the requisition can be converted into a PO, but it does not block MRP from considering the requirement. Hence, MD04 in 1008 shows the dependent requirement even for STRs that are not yet approved.

Options to handle this

1. Use Release Indicator to Control MRP Relevance
In release strategy configuration SPRO → Materials Management → Purchasing → Purchase Requisition → Release Procedure, you can set the release indicator to determine whether the requisition is “blocked” for further processing. If you configure the release indicator so that unreleased STRs are not relevant for MRP, then only approved STRs will be considered in the supplying plant. This requires customizing the release indicator to affect MRP explosion. This requires careful customizing because unreleased STRs remain in the requesting plant, but are not exploded into dependent requirements in the supplying plant until the release indicator changes to “Released.” In practice, this is achieved by using different release indicators tied to different processing flags (e.g., “blocked for follow‑on processing”).

2. Separate Document Types for STRs
Use a different PR document type for STRs that are subject to release. Configure MRP so that only requisitions with a certain document type (or release status) are considered in the supplying plant. This way, unreleased STRs remain invisible to MRP in 1008.

3. BAdI / User Exit Enhancement
Standard SAP does not automatically exclude unreleased STRs from MRP. You can use enhancement spots such as BAdI MD_PURREQ_RELEASE or exits in MRP run to filter out unreleased STRs. This is a common approach when business requires strict dependency on release approval.

4. Workflow / Process Control
Instead of trying to block MRP, you can control the timing of MRP runs in plant 1008. Run MRP in 1008 only after STRs in 1003 have been approved. This is a process workaround rather than configuration, but it ensures dependent requirements are aligned with approvals.

entry.title: Cloud connector to cloud alm configuration
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We are currently working on connecting the Cloud Connector to the cloud and enabling Health Monitoring in Cloud ALM.

While reviewing the SAP Help Portal documentation, we noticed that it mentions the need to create LDAP-based user management for data collection to push data from the Cloud Connector to Cloud ALM.

Could you please clarify the following points:

  • Is it PERSON_NAME to implement LDAP-based user management for this configuration?
  • Can we assign the required monitoring roles to the existing admin user and proceed without LDAP?
  • If LDAP-based configuration is implemented, we observed that the admin user becomes inactive. Could you confirm if this is expected behavior?

Your guidance on the above queries would be greatly appreciated.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Cloud connector to cloud alm configuration
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Greetings from SAP Support.

Please find our clarification below:

 

1.Is it mandatory to implement LDAP-based user management for this configuration?

No, LDAP-based user management is not mandatory for enabling data collection from SAP Cloud Connector to SAP Cloud ALM.

Cloud Connector has just one Administrator user named Administrator by default. It is possible to change the name and password of this user but it is not possible to add additional users.

To be able to add additional users to Cloud Connector, technically it is required to configure the Cloud Connector to use an LDAP user store.

See KBA3528028 - Cloud Connector user requirements to connect to Cloud ALM - SAP for Me 

 

2.Can we assign the required monitoring roles to the existing admin user and proceed without LDAP?

Yes. You can assign the required monitoring and data collection roles directly to the existing Cloud Connector administrator user and proceed without configuring LDAP-based user management. 

 

3.If LDAP-based configuration is implemented, we observed that the admin user becomes inactive. Could you confirm if this is expected behavior?

Yes, this is expected behavior.

Once configured, the default Cloud Connector Administrator user becomes inactive and can no longer be used to log on to the Cloud Connector. 

See Help Portal https://help.sap.com/docs/connectivity/sap-btp-connectivity-cf/configure-named-cloud-connector-users

 

Best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Material Ledger handling for Group Valuation (4G) whe...
entry.content:
Good day @edoymaner 

Thank you for your question

There are a few aspects to consider in your quest.

  • You cannot technically deactivate Group Valuation once you have activated it. This means that 4G valuation view will continue to receive postings from your goods movements and invoice receipts, even if you do not use it for your reporting acitivities.
  • You cannot run CKMLCP in public cloud as it is an on premise-based term. In public cloud, you can execute the same business function through the use of the Fiori actual costing apps and closing tasks. So, the question becomes: Do you need to run actual costing closing steps for 4G valuation view?.
  • You can usually minimise or avoid 4G effort by not processing 4G in the actual costing run template, as long as you are not using any of the 4G results (such as prices, revaluation, actual cost component split) operationally or for your reporting.

Best practice approach is to:

  1. Configure your settings in a way so that your Group Valuation produces the same result as Legal Valuation. Keep the approaches aligned and avoid any configuration that intentionally creates different valuation result between legal and group. See Configuration and Actual Costing Run Result Activity Data for more details.
  2. Run the ML actual costing as normal but treat 4G in your operations as not for reporting. Make sure you keep reporting and business users on Legal valuation views only.
  3. Reduce your effort by automating and not by excluding configuration. Considering the public cloud does not provide the option to exclude valuation view 4G from ML closing, the realistic way to minimise your effort is to schedule the period end steps and standardise a checklist so 4G is always closed together with the other views. See Actual Costing Run Result Activity Data for more insights.
  4. If you keep 4G aligned the extra view should remain low impact. Monitor price differences and your settlement outcomes. If any differences appear, they should usually indicate a divergence in your currency setup or your valuation logic but not a missing step.

To summarise:

  • Active Valuation in public cloud behaves as n active valuation view in ML.
  • You cannot configure ML to skip period end processing only for the 4G view.
  • Keep Group Valuation neutral by aligning valuation logic with legal.
  • Run ML actual costing and close steps as normal, while you restrict reporting to Legal valuation views.
  • Doing these will minimise your effort without you trying any unsupported deactivation patterns.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Public Cloud - Copy inspection results from SFG to FG
entry.content:
With 200, the system expects a clear link between the FG inspection lot and the SFG inspection lot via the material master and inspection plan hierarchy. If that link isn’t established, the system cannot “find” the preliminary product lot and throws the error.

Check the below areas

In the FG material master, the preliminary product (SFG) must be defined correctly in the BOM/routing so that the system knows which inspection lot belongs to the preliminary product. If the FG inspection lot cannot trace back to the SFG material, the copy fails.

The FG inspection plan must reference the MICs with Results Data Origin = 200. The SFG inspection lot must exist and be completed before the FG lot is created. Otherwise, the system won’t find it.

The SFG inspection lot must be in a status where results are recorded and available (e.g., RREC). If the lot is still open or not valuated, the system won’t allow copying.

Since 300 is not available, you cannot manually select lots. The system only auto‑links based on the preliminary product relationship. That means the prerequisite is: the FG inspection lot must have a direct predecessor lot for the SFG material, otherwise the error appears.

entry.title: Re: BOM can only be extended via Master Recipe
entry.content:
Below are the likely root causes

  • The material in question is probably maintained with a recipe‑based production process (Process Manufacturing) rather than discrete manufacturing.
  • In SAP, materials flagged for process industries (PI) use Master Recipes instead of BOMs for component assignment.
  • That’s why when you try CS01 (create BOM), the system tells you “BOM can only be extended via Master Recipe.”
  • For such materials, the system expects you to maintain the component structure in the Master Recipe (transaction C201/C202), not in a BOM.

entry.title: Re: Intercompany stock transfer what happens when a lower...
entry.content:
In your case, what happens when quantities differ is as follows:

NBIC order creation:
Represents the expected inbound from the vendor/3rd party warehouse.

Putaway message via Boomi:
Updates the inbound delivery with the actual quantity received at the external warehouse.

Job posting GR:
Moves stock from “in transit” into the receiving plant’s available stock.

If the actual received quantity ≠ ordered quantity:

Less stock arrives:
You post GR for the actual received quantity. The NBIC order remains partially open until you either receive the remainder or close it. To close, you must reduce the inbound delivery quantity (adjust delivery against PO) so that the open balance is zero. The difference is then cleared, and stock in transit is reduced accordingly.

More stock arrives:
You cannot post more than the ordered quantity against the NBIC order. The excess must be handled by creating a new NBIC order/inbound delivery or by adjusting the PO/inbound delivery quantity before GR. Otherwise, the system will reject the GR posting.

entry.title: About SAP Cloud ALM roles
entry.content:
Regarding SAP Cloud ALM roles, does the common topic "Cross Global Administrator" include all other roles?
Do roles in the implementation phase need to be assigned individually?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: About SAP Cloud ALM roles
entry.content:
Available Roles outlines that Role Collection "Cross Global Administrator" permits users to "Create and manage all SAP Cloud ALM objects, except for personal or sensitive data". 

Role Collection "Cross Global Administrator" should only be assigned to a user fulfilling the role of Administrator for the SAP Cloud ALM tenant. It should not be used for general day-to-day work. Instead, more specific role collections should be assigned to the users based on the tasks that they will perform. SAP Cloud ALM has documented these role collections and categorized them based on several scenarios:

  • Implementation
  • Transformation
  • Operations
  • Service
  • Administration
  • RISE with SAP Methodology

Additional information about the Implementation scenario can be found in KBAs 3499177 and 3643702.

entry.title: The behavior of dimension member comparison in Advanced Formulas
entry.content:
Introduction

You can use the various objects in an IF condition.  Among them, the behavior of comparing a dimension member with another dimension member from a different dimension, or with a dimension property (which is also a dimension member), is explained through an example.

 

IF with dimension combination filters

You can define a dimension combination filter that produces a scope of dimension member combinations based on whether or not the other dimension ID or dimension properties match.

 

Example

Compare the Dimension with the Other dimension property

Model & Dimension

Company_Code Dimension

Cost_Center Dimension

 

Calculation Source

 

 

Case 1:  [d/Company_Code] = [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode]

MEMBERSET [d/Company_Code] = ("100", "200")
MEMBERSET [d/Cost_Center] = ("CC100", "CC200","CC300")

IF [d/Company_Code] = [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode] THEN
	DELETE()
ENDIF

     Calculated Result

    All combinations of Company Code (100 or 200) and the CompanyCode property (100, 200, or 300) return true.

    As a result, six records are deleted.

 

 

Case 2:  [d/Company_Code] != [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode]

MEMBERSET [d/Company_Code] = ("100", "200")
MEMBERSET [d/Cost_Center] = ("CC100", "CC200","CC300")

IF [d/Company_Code] != [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode] THEN
	DELETE()
ENDIF

   Calculated Result

   There are no combinations other than all combinations of Company Code (100 or 200) and the CompanyCode property (100, 200, or 300). Therefore, no records are deleted.

 

 

Case 3:  [d/Company_Code] == [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode]

MEMBERSET [d/Company_Code] = ("100", "200")
MEMBERSET [d/Cost_Center] = ("CC100", "CC200","CC300")

IF [d/Company_Code] == [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode] THEN
	DELETE()
ENDIF

   Calculated Result

   For each record, the combination where the Company Code and the CompanyCode property match returns true. As a result, two records are deleted.

 

 

Case 4:  [d/Company_Code] !== [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode]

MEMBERSET [d/Company_Code] = ("100", "200")
MEMBERSET [d/Cost_Center] = ("CC100", "CC200","CC300")

IF [d/Company_Code] !== [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode] THEN
	DELETE()
ENDIF

   Calculated Result

   For each record, the combinations where the Company Code and the CompanyCode property do not match return true. As a result, 4 records are deleted.

 

Thanks,

Moonjun

entry.title: Re: SAP public cloud custom po header condition for freig...
entry.content:
Good day @R971 

Thank you for your question

It is important to note that, in PO pricing, the system considers Amount as rate, while condition value is the calculated value after the system has applied the condition across items. So, if your custom condition is currently being treated as an item applied condition, the system will apply the 50 to each PO item and the condition value becomes 100 when there are two items.

If the 50 is your total for the whole PO, then you must configure your condition and use it as a header condition with distribution.

I suggest you evaluate the following:

First step:

  • You open your Purchasing Calculation Schema where your condition is used. Then open the ZFIN condition type and verify you have configured it as a Header condition and not item.
  • Ensure it also supports Header distribution, so one header amount is distributed to item rather than copied to each of them. See Purchasing Pricing Condition Record Events for more details.

Second step:

In your Manage Purchase Orders app, open your PO, go to your conditions at header level and enter your total freight 50. Use the distribution function so the system splits the 50 across items (based on your configuration, this is usually by item value or quantity).

Third step:

After you have carried out the distribution, header should show total of 50, items should show prorated values sum of 50 and your PO total should reflect the correct overall freight.

If you cannot change your configuration now, you can get to 50 total for 2 items by entering 25. This is suggested as a workaround and not a long-term solution.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP public cloud custom po header condition for freig...
entry.content:
Dear @R971,

Your condition type is acting as a non-group condition

SAP behavior is documented for Public Cloud:

  • Group condition = ON, system distributes the header condition value to items proportionally and sum of items = header value
  • Group condition = OFF, system copies the same value to every item

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3618341

That exactly explains why each PO item gets the same 50

To fix this you need two things:

Point 1. Fix the condition type

In CBC go to 101094(Define Condition Types - Set Pricing Condition Types – Purchasing)

For ZFIN:

1. Set the Calculation Type to match your intent:

    • If you want 50 total per PO, use Fixed Amount, not per unit/quantity

2. Set Group Condition = ON so that header entry gets distributed, not copied

SAP Note below as example:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003618341

Point 2. Fix the calculation schema / pricing procedure line

In CBC go to 101095(Set Calculation Schema – Purchasing) and ensure:

1. ZFIN is marked as a Header condition line in the schema header indicator on the pricing-procedure line

2. You do not have ZFIN duplicated as an item condition line in the same schema that can also lead to unexpected doubling/copying

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003043325

Point 3. Re-test the PO

After transporting the config:

  • Enter 50 at header for ZFIN
  • Items should show distributed amounts
  • Sum of item condition values = 50, not 100

Best Regards,

Dawid
